Ian Badcoe wrote:

>	These scores all have the properties:
>1) a "perfect" player will score 1.0000.
>2) only illegal moves can drive a score negative.
>3) players that cannot make illegal moves (some approaches won't allow 
>this) will score the same on legal and non-legal forms.
>
>  
>
Can you just clarify one point for me - is the score you describe 
assigned to each move? If so then won't the overall score be >1 for a 
perfect player (total or average score for all moves).

I reckon this is a step in the right direction re the need for some kind 
of universal evaluation scheme. Not sure about the evaluation of 
performance against poor players aspect. If we are evaluating against 
every board state then surely some of those states could only have been 
obtained by poor/illogical play (or what we would consider to be poor 
play under normal circumstances) and therefore we *are* evaluating 
performance against some poor players, aren't we?

I suppose a truly universal evaluation scheme would evaluate a player's 
ability to learn how other players play and thus exploit their 
weaknesses, but do you give each player an ID so we know which players 
we are playing against or do you leave it to the algorithm to analyse 
the style of play and to adjust it's playing strategy accordingly? 
Consider that I'm a human playing TTT with an anonymous player over the 
internet, do I try some silly moves in an attenpt to find weaknesses or 
do I play primarily defensively and only offensively as a secondary 
strategy. I do the later but I do take advantage of any silly moves the 
opponent makes,  but if my defensive style of play doesn't expose the 
opponents silly moves then I never discover them. 

So what we are proposing is evaluation assuming a reasonably competent 
opponent and a fixed (non-adapting) strategy.

Colin.
